title: How Fixing My Sleep Hygiene Finally Helped Me Rest With Chronic Pain

content: For as long as I can remember, sleep and I have been in a complicated situationship. I’d wake up multiple times every night, toss and turn in pain, stare at the ceiling for hours, and then wake up feeling like I hadn’t slept at all. It didn’t matter how early I went to bed, how tired I was, or how badly I wanted to rest. My body had other plans.

This wasn’t the occasional rough night. This was my normal. I grew up thinking everyone woke up four or five times a night. I thought everyone took forever to fall asleep. I thought everyone started the morning already exhausted. Chronic pain from psoriatic arthritis only made things worse. Lying still hurt, turning over hurt, getting comfortable hurt, staying comfortable hurt. Sleep just wasn’t restorative.

I didn’t realize how much this constant sleep disruption affected my life until I started trying to fix it. What I learned surprised me. I used to believe poor sleep was just part of having chronic pain, something I had no control over. And while pain definitely plays a role, it turned out many of my sleep struggles were habits my body had learned over years of not knowing any better.

content: A few months ago, I started a journey to try improving my sleep hygiene. I didn’t expect miracles. Honestly, I didn’t expect anything at all, I just wanted to see. But the changes I made slowly added up, and now I sleep better than I ever have in my entire life.
Here’s exactly what I did, how long it took, and what changed.
Creating a Wind-Down Routine

The biggest shift started with deciding that sleep wasn’t just something that “happened.” I needed to treat it like the essential part of my health that it is. So I built a wind-down routine that starts about an hour and a half before I want to be asleep.
This became non-negotiable. I had to treat it the same way I treat taking medication or going to a doctor’s appointment, something I do for my body whether I feel like it or not.

content: My wind-down routine isn’t complicated. It usually looks like this:
bullets: A few minutes of gentle stretching or nightly yoga
Deep breathing exercises or a guided relaxation
No scrolling, no notifications, no phone
Dim lights and soft music if I need it

content: I created a rhythm that told my brain, “We’re done for the day. It’s safe to slow down.”

The surprising thing? I didn’t have to do anything extreme. I didn’t turn into someone who sleeps with a cup of chamomile tea and writes gratitude letters before bed. I just created consistency, and my body eventually followed.
Stopping My Nighttime Wanderings

One of my worst sleep habits was getting out of bed when I woke up in the middle of the night. I wasn’t doing anything wild – sometimes I’d scroll my phone, pet the cat; sometimes I’d wander to the kitchen for a little snack. I thought this helped me “reset,” but it actually trained my brain to stay awake.
When I learned that getting out of bed reinforces the idea that nighttime is not for sleeping, I felt personally attacked.
So I made myself stop. If I woke up, I stayed in bed. I didn’t reach for my phone. I didn’t get a snack. I didn’t go pee. I didn’t reward my insomnia with entertainment.

content: At first, it felt impossible. I was awake and frustrated and convinced I’d never fall back asleep. But over time, my body got the hint. Instead of waking up and fully activating, I started drifting back to sleep more easily. What used to be an hourlong event turned into five minutes of half-conscious tossing before I dozed off again.
Keeping the Same Sleep and Wake Times, Even on Weekends
This was brutal at first, but it mattered more than I expected.

I set a bedtime. I set a wake-up time. And I followed them every single day. Yes, even on weekends. Yes, even when I was tempted to stay up late. Yes, even when I wanted to sleep in because I felt terrible.

content: Our bodies love routines. Mine didn’t know what to do before because every day looked different. Sleeping in on weekends made Mondays feel even worse. Staying up late made the next night harder. I never had a regulated rhythm.

content: This step alone changed everything. Once my body knew when to expect sleep, it stopped fighting me so hard. It wasn’t immediate, but the shift was noticeable after a few weeks.
Cutting Out Naps and Cutting Down Time in Bed
This one hurt my soul. I love naps. I love the idea of naps. I love the fantasy that a 2 p.m. nap will repair everything wrong with me.

But naps were destroying my nighttime sleep. Even short ones made it harder to fall asleep later. So I cut them out or at least cut them out most of the time, because psoriatic arthritis is unpredictable and sometimes my body genuinely needs a nap. I just stopped using them as a default coping mechanism.
I also stopped lying in bed doing anything other than sleeping. No phone, no TV, no doomscrolling, no emails, no games. If I was in bed, it was sleep time. Period.
This retrained my brain to associate my bed with rest, not entertainment or stress or distraction.

sections.heading: Realizing Waking Up at the Same Times Every Night Was Just a Habit
content: This might be the wildest thing I learned through all of this: Waking up at the same times every night wasn’t a mystery or a symptom. It was a habit.
My body had essentially set alarms for itself.

Once I changed my routine, those “alarms” slowly faded. I still wake up sometimes, since chronic pain means I’ll probably never sleep like a cartoon character, but the consistency and intensity of the nighttime wakeups have decreased dramatically. And I fall back asleep so much faster. Plus, this meant I was getting more sleep time in.
And the difference that makes for my energy? Life-changing.
It Didn’t Happen Overnight
This process wasn’t quick. I didn’t fix my sleep in a week. It wasn’t pretty. It was uncomfortable. It required patience.

content: The first few weeks honestly felt worse. My body fought every change. The afternoon crash had me craving naps so hard. Everything felt unfamiliar. But around the two-month mark, something shifted. My sleep started deepening. My wakeups got shorter. My bedtime felt natural instead of forced.

But around the two-month mark, something shifted. My sleep started deepening. My wakeups got shorter. My bedtime felt natural instead of forced.

content: I kept going. And one day, I realized something shocking:
I was falling asleep in under 10 minutes.
I didn’t remember tossing and turning. I didn’t stare at the ceiling thinking about every embarrassing thing I’ve ever said. I didn’t scroll through TikTok until I dissociated. I just … fell asleep.

Then I noticed I was staying asleep longer. I started sleeping through the night more often. And I started having intense, vivid dreams – the kind you get when you’re finally reaching deeper stages of sleep.
For the first time in my life, I woke up and thought, “Wow … I actually rested.”
It felt like a miracle, but it wasn’t. It was the result of months of small, consistent changes that gave my body the time it needed to relearn what sleep was supposed to feel like.
I Still Have Chronic Pain – But Now I Have Rest, Too

I’m not magically cured. Chronic pain will always affect my sleep. There will still be nights when my joints ache or my tendons throb or I wake up uncomfortable. That’s part of life with psoriatic arthritis.

content: But now I have tools. I have habits. I have structure. My body is learning how to rest even when it hurts.
Creating healthy sleep hygiene didn’t fix everything, but it improved enough that my days feel lighter and my energy feels more stable. I feel more regulated. I feel more human.
And the biggest change? I finally know what it feels like to wake up rested. That alone makes every slow, frustrating step worth it.
